item.description:
NEW HAMPSHIRE SERIES:
Zealand Mountain, Mount Guyot, West Bond, Mount Bond and Bondcliff

EVENT ORGANIZER: Julie Moran. Please contact me here with your thoughts, ideas and suggestions about this trip: jmmoran {{AT}} nycap.rr.com, Mobile 518-281-5882. PLEASE -- no calls except for day-of scheduling issues. You can text me as well. FINISH YOUR NH 48 4,000 LIST WITH US!


ESSENTIAL TRIP DETAILS

Difficulty: 19.2 miles, 3,338' ASL climb; at a 1.5 mile / hour pace this is about a 13-hour hike.

Car Spot Time: 6:30 a.m.

Hike Start: 7:30 a.m.

CLICK HERE: Google Maps Trailhead Directions, Distances (link) from the CAR SPOT LOCATION -- LINCOLN WOOD VISITORS CENTER (ALL HIKERS MEET HERE), on the Kancamagus Highway (NH Route 112), near Lincoln, NH; to the trailhead at the end of Zealand Road, off of U.S. 302, east of Twin Mountain , NH.


Standing on the edge of Bondcliff ...



TRIP SUMMARY AND UPDATE (08/18/2010 7:30 p.m.): This trip is a cross-posted event between Hiking Mates CHALLENGE, the New England Hiking Meetup (NEHM) and the 4-Seasons-Hiking-Group. The current plan is to meet at the Lincoln Woods Visitor's Center as a car spot at 6:30 a.m. -- I will be spending the night there -- and then drive around to the Zealand Road / Zealand Trailhead. Please email me with your thoughts about this schedule / plan ... and stay close to the website for updates. NOTE: This is a dog-friendly hike (i.e., Mike is going!).


ESSENTIALS TO BRING: Flash light AND head lamp, food / snacks / at least three bottles of water, first aid items, sunscreen, bug repellent. Wear multiple layers of synthetic materials for warmth; trekking poles may be helpful gear for this hike. TEST YOUR LIGHTS!!!


RESEARCH ESSENTIALS:

CLICK HERE FOR A TRIP PLANNER OF THE HIKE ROUTE -- PRINT AND TAKE A COPY WITH YOU (be sure to click the correct link at bottom, "Zealand Rd to Rte 112 w-o Hale."


A late-summer view from the Zealand Falls Hut ...



WEB RESEARCH LINKS

TRAIL DESCRIPTIONS AND TRIP REPORTS
Link, Area Overview
Link, Up-To-Date Trail Conditions

Link, Trail Description - Zealand Trail
Link, Trail Description - Twinway Trail
Link, Trail Description - Bondcliff Trail

Link, SummitPost Page
Link, Appalachian Mountain Club Page
Link, PeakBagger Page

Link, SummitPost Page
Link, Appalachian Mountain Club Page
Link, PeakBagger Page

Mount Bond
[Link, SummitPost Page
Link, Appalachian Mountain Club Page
Link, PeakBagger Page

Bondcliff
Link, SummitPost Page
Link, Appalachian Mountain Club Page
Link, PeakBagger Page


[EDITED FROM "NETFIRMS"] This trip begins on the Zealand Trail that runs from the end of the Zealand Road to the junction with the Ethan Pond and Twinway Trails near the AMC Zealand Falls Hut. Most of the trail follows an old railroad grade with slight uphill, but a few places where the grade is eroded or muddy the trail takes a rougher bypass route. Most of the brook crossings have wide bridges for skiing, but half a dozen minor ones require hopping on rocks. The Zealand Railroad was unique among logging lines in that it was actually chartered as a mainline railroad authorized to connect to other railroads -- in particular the Boston & Maine in North Woodstock -- to provide a shorter route from Concord to the Crawford Notch region. When logging ended, the right-of-way was deeded to the Boston & Maine, but the state charter was allowed to lapse when engineers determined the connection would be too costly.

The Twinway runs from the junction of the Frost Trail and the Garfield Ridge Trail near the AMC Galehead Hut to the junction of the Zealand Trail and the Ethan Pond Trail near the AMC Zealand Falls Hut. It is part of the Appalachian Trail and hence in summer receives heavy overnight use by backpackers as well as hut-hoppers. The trail roughly follows the Ammonoosuc-Pemigewasset divide and while it doesn't pass over every bump there is a lot of up and down. In spite of the many waterbars and rock steps placed by trail workers, there are still plenty of eroded rocky sections and ledges to scramble.

The Bondcliff Trail leads from the Wilderness Trail about 4.7 miles from NH Route 112 to the Twinway near the Mount Guyot summit. It passes over Mount Bond and The Cliffs of Mount Bond, hence its name. Most of the trail is in woods with moderate grades, but the section over The Cliffs is an extensive boulder field exposed to winds, and there are small alpine zones on Mount Bond and Mount Guyot. The Bonds are among the New Hampshire 4000-footers that are furthest from a paved road, and each summit offers 360-degree views. Less than .1 mile further on the Wilderness Trail from where the Bondcliff Trail turns off is the last remaining logging railroad trestle in New Hampshire. According to C. Francis Belcher in Logging Railroads of the White Mountains: "The next time you are anywhere near this spot, go out of your way to inspect this remarkable antique. Men don't build or care for structures like it today." Unfortunately he is correct -- the Forest Service has proposed to remove it as a non-conforming structure in Wilderness.


At the summit of Bond, looking west to Bondcliff down the ridge.



NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any challenge hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going and how to get back.

WEATHER AND OTHER SUDDEN EVENTS CAN CAUSE SUDDEN CHANGES TO OR CANCELLATION OF THIS EVENT. YOU MUST CHECK BACK TO THE MEETUP.COM SITE OFTEN FOR UPDATES TO ANY HIKING MATES CHALLENGE EVENT. BY ATTENDING YOU'VE AGREED THAT YOU'VE READ INFORMATION PRESENTED HERE AND AT OUR GUIDELINES -- CLICK THE "ABOUT" LINK AT LEFT.

See you there! Julie.
